awd_titl_txt: Magnetically-Assisted Laser-Induced Plasma Micro-Machining for Flexible and Fast Texturing of Functional Surfaces
awd_abstract_narration:
Challenges in the energy, environmental, and health sectors present a growing need for flexible and scalable micro-machining processes for applications such as textured surfaces for tissue adhesion and anti-bio-fouling, reduced wear in tooling and engine systems, and functional surfaces for biomedical devices such as needles and implants. This award funds research on a novel micro-machining process that addresses several existing challenges, namely limitations in the machinability of materials, patterning large areas at economically feasible material removal rates, and generating micro-features of different sizes and shapes.  A fully realized magnetically-assisted laser induced plasma micro-machining process will be capable of fast and direct generation of micro-features with controlled geometrical characteristics.

In magnetically-assisted laser-induced plasma micro-machining, picosecond laser pulses induce a plasma plume within a liquid dielectric. The plasma plume removes material from the workpiece surface by a combination of thermal vaporization and mechanical erosion to create machined features with desired geometry. This project aims to advance processing capabilities in terms of machining rate and precision by utilizing the external magnetic field's influence on the plasma plume through two mechanisms: (1) by increasing its energy density, leading to increased material removal rates; and (2) by modifying its shape, leading to the nearly direct creation of desired micro-feature geometries. The research objective is to understand the interaction between the electromagnetic and thermo-mechanical mechanisms of the process, i.e., interactions between the laser, dielectric, plasma, magnetic field and workpiece material. Methods to achieve this objective include simulations using magneto-hydrodynamic, particle-in-cell and finite element analysis methods to determine the outcomes of each interaction. Experiments with a wide variety of materials, including titanium alloys, silicon, polymers, and transparent, brittle and reflective materials such as glass, will be conducted using a picosecond laser system with a 532 nm wavelength, a computer-controlled array of electromagnets, and focus variation-based metrology. Experimental results will be compared with simulation results in terms of the depth and shape of the generated features and material removal rate.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
There is a growing need for flexible and scalable micro-machining processes to address energy, environmental and health challenges through applications such as textured surfaces for tissue adhesion lower friction and reduced wear in tooling and engine systems, and functional surfaces for biomedical equipment such as needles, stents and implants. These are only some of the countless applications in the biomedical, electronics, aerospace, communications, optics and defense sectors that require tightly controlled micro-manufacturing operations. To overcome existing challenges of current processes, e.g., limitations in material removal ability, patterning large areas at economically feasible material removal rates, and generating arbitrary geometric micro-scale features of different sizes and shapes, the conception and analysis of a newly proposed process - Magnetically-Controlled Laser-Induced Plasma Micro-Machining (MC-LIPMM) - that addresses several of these limitations was the aim of this work.

In MC-LIPMM, picosecond laser pulses induce a plasma plume within a liquid dielectric, e.g., distilled water. The plasma plume removes material from the workpiece surface by a combination of thermal vaporization and mechanical erosion to create machined features with desired geometry. The aim of the current work was to establish a fundamental understanding of the process physics and advance processing capabilities in terms of machining rate and precision by utilizing the influence of static and dynamic external magnetic field on the plasma plume. Two mechanisms were investigated: (1) increasing the plasma?s energy density to increase material removal rates; and (2) modifying the shape of the plasma to facilitate the nearly direct creation of desired micro-feature geometries. The overarching research objective was to understand the interaction between the electromagnetic and thermo-mechanical mechanisms of the process, i.e., the interactions between the laser, dielectric, plasma, magnetic field, and workpiece material. To this end, theoretical models of some of the key physical phenomena were formulated, plasma behavior in magnetic fields of different density and configuration was experimentally investigated, and process feasibility in terms of its precision and efficiency in comparison to customary laser ablation processes assessed.

The unique properties of the process including its high machining throughput, multi-material processing capability, flexible shape generation ability and rapid in-situ feature geometry modifications will enable it to be employed in various applications ranging from demanding surface texturing processes to free-form surface micro-machining. The compact nature of the apparatus and the anticipated stability of the process will allow it to be deployed in multiple environments. Moreover, the low adverse impact of the process on material characteristics due to its small heat affected zone will enable MC-LIPMM to be applied in all industrial sectors in need for high-precision manufacture of micro-scale components and features. The multi-disciplinary nature of the theoretical and experimental activities has also offered a fertile ground for engaging and exposing students to advanced manufacturing process research and development. 

 

 

 


Last Modified: 10/24/2021
Modified by: Kornel F Ehmann
